Title:
On the phylogenetic positions of the Australian ferns
Coveniella and Oenotrichia
Keywords:
Dryopteridaceae, monilophytes, eupolypods, Polypodiales,
classification, systematics, phylogeny
Abstract:
Two Australian fern generaCoveniella (monotypic) and
Oenotrichia (two species)–are examined for their phylogenetic placement
within the Dryopteridaceae. They are resolved within a clade of
Lastreopsis, Megalastrum and Rumohra, with strong support. Lastreopsis
is recovered as polyphyletic, and the two Australia genera are nested in
one of the polyphyletic groups. Compared to the related genera,
Coveniella exhibits unique morphology through its once-pinnate fronds.
On the other hand, Oenotrichia is distinguished via several characters
including the position of the sori, frond indument, and scales. In order
to resolve the taxonomy of Australian Oenotrichia, which are clearly
separate from Oenotrichia s.s. in the Dennstaedtiaceae, a new generic
name is proposed, Dantela Nagalingum gen. nov. The new genus is endemic
to Australia and is restricted to the northeastern Queensland
region.
